items.description: River Thames and its tributaries from Days Lock to above Pangbourne

floodArea.riverOrSea: River Thames, Lady Brook, Ewelme Stream, Mill Brook, West Hagbourne Stream, Hakkas Brook, Cholsey Brook, Kibble Ditch

items.message:
Property flooding is not expected. River levels on the Thames are gradually rising. Flooding of low lying land, roads and  is expected to continue today, 25/09/2024, and overnight in the Wallingford and Goring areas. Further rainfall is forecast today with the potential to be heavy at times. We expect river levels to continue gradually rising throughout today and overnight as water moves downstream.
Our staff are managing weirs on the River Thames to reduce flood risk. Avoid using low lying footpaths near local watercourses. Go to the 'River and Sea levels in England' webpage for current river levels. This message will be updated by this evening, 25/09/24, or as the situation changes.

items.description: River Cherwell from Lower Heyford down to and including Oxford

floodArea.riverOrSea: River Cherwell, Woodeaton Brook, Bayswater Brook, Marston Brook, Peasmoor Brook

items.message:
Property flooding is expected. A flood warning is in force for the River Cherwell at Lower Heyford. River levels are high on the Lower River Cherwell following recent heavy rain. Therefore, flooding of property, low lying land and roads is expected to continue today, 25/09/2024, especially in areas closest to the River Cherwell between Heyford and Oxford. Further rainfall is forecast today with the potential to be heavy at times. River levels are expected to rise again this afternoon in response to forecast rainfall.
Our staff have been checking and clearing trash screens in the area and we are closely monitoring the situation. Avoid using low lying footpaths near local watercourses. Go to the 'River and Sea levels in England' webpage for current river levels. This message will be updated this evening, 25/09/2024, or as the situation changes.

We are monitoring the situation. Go to the 'River and Sea levels in England' webpage for current river levels. Avoid contact with flood water. 

This message will be updated by tomorrow morning, 26/09/24, or as the situation changes.

items.message:

Further rainfall is forecast today with the potential to be heavy at times. River levels are falling but remain sensitive to any further rainfall. 
Our staff are checking and clearing trash screens. We are monitoring the situation. Avoid using low lying footpaths near local watercourses. Go to the 'River and Sea levels in England' webpage for current river levels. This message will be updated this evening, 25/09/2024, or as the situation changes.

items.message:
Property flooding is expected. Flood warnings are in force for the River Ray at Islip and for the Murcott area. River levels have stabilised on the upper River Ray but levels continue to gradually rise at Islip. Therefore, flooding of low lying land and roads is expected today, 25/09/2024 and overnight, especially in areas closest to the River Ray between Lower Arncott and Islip. Further rainfall is forecast today with the potential to be heavy at times. River levels are expected to continue gradually rising at Islip throughtout today.
Our staff have been checking and clearing trash screens in the area and we are closely monitoring the situation. Avoid using low lying footpaths near local watercourses. Go to the 'River and Sea levels in England' webpage for current river levels. This message will be updated by this evening, 25/09/2024, or as the situation changes.

items.description: Colne Brook at Iver and Colnbrook

floodArea.county: Buckinghamshire, Greater London, Hillingdon, Slough, Surrey, Windsor and Maidenhead

items.message:
River levels on the Colne Brook are beginning to fall after the recent heavy rainfall. 

Flooding may still affect locations near the Colne Brook and Lower Colne, with low lying land and roads expected to be most affected, particularly around Colnbrook Village, Poyle, Albany Park, High Street, Mill Street, Fawsley Close and Myrtle Close.

Further rainfall is forecast overnight and into tomorrow, Thursday 26th September, so we may see levels rise again.

We are monitoring rainfall and river levels, and checking rivers for blockages. Take care and avoid walking, cycling or driving through flood water.

This message will be updated by 9am Thursday 26th September, or as the situation changes.

items.message:
Property flooding is expected. Flood warning are in force for the River Thame from Chisleampton to Drayton St Leonard and at Dorchester. River levels are high along much of the River Thame and as a result of recent heavy rain. Therefore, flooding of property, low lying land, and roads is expected to continue today, 25/09/2024, especially in the areas closest to Dorchester. 
Further rainfall is forecast today with the potential to be heavy at times. River levels are falling in the upper reaches of the River Thame around Aylesbury, but remain high further downstream. River levels remain sensitive to further rainfall.
Our staff are checking and clearing trash screens in the area. We are monitoring the situation. Avoid using low lying footpaths near local watercourses. Go to the 'River and Sea levels in England' webpage for current river levels. This message will be updated this evening, 25/09/2024, or as the situation changes.

items.message:
River levels are beginning to fall on the Lower River Colne and Frays River, however further rain is forecast with the potential for heavy rain Thursday evening, so river levels may rise again.

Flooding may continue to affect low-lying land and roads, particularly in the Thorney Mill Road and Cricketfield Road areas, which may impact Riverside Mobile Home Park.

We are closely monitoring the situation and checking rivers for blockages. Avoid using low lying footpaths and any bridges near local watercourses, and monitor local water levels and weather conditions.

This message will be updated by 9am tomorrow, Thursday 26th September, or as the situation changes.

items.description: Wear estuary
items.message:
High tides, strong winds and large waves may lead to flooding tomorrow morning.
Tides will be at their highest from 8:00 AM to 13:00 PM tomorrow, 26/09/2024, with wave overtopping during these times.
Waves are forecast to overtop coastal defences at riverside footpaths and low lying land and roads. The area most affected will be Port of Sunderland Harbour.
After the high tide tomorrow morningâ€š the weather is more settled and no flooding is expected.
We are closely monitoring the situation.
Be careful along beaches, promenades, coastal footpaths and roads as large waves and sea spray could be dangerous.
This message will be updated by 13:00 PM on 26/09/2024, or as the situation changes.

items.description: Upper Avon River Swift and Clay Coton Brook
items.message: River levels remain high but are beginning to fall at the Lilbourne river gauge as a result of heavy rainfall. Consequently, the risk of flooding remains. We expect flooding to affect low-lying land and roads adjacent to River Avon between Stanford and Rugby, River Swift between Cosford and Rugby and Clay Coton Brook between Yelvertoft and Lilbourne. We are closely monitoring the situation. Our incident response staff are actively checking river levels and the weather forecast. Please avoid using low lying footpaths and bridges near local watercourses and plan driving routes to avoid low lying roads near rivers, which may be flooded. This message will be updated by 12:00 on 26/09/2024, or as the situation changes.

items.description: River Sow and River Penk

floodArea.riverOrSea: Sandyford Brook, Ridings Brook, Saredon Brook

items.message:
River levels remain high but are falling at the Milford river gauge following heavy rainfall last weekend.  Consequently, flooding of roads and farmland remains possible throughout today and into tomorrow, 26/09/2024.  Flooding is affecting low-lying land and roads adjacent to the River Sow between Great Bridgeford and Shugborough, the River Penk between Coven and Stafford, the Sandyford Brook, the Rising Brook, the Ridings Brook and the Saredon Brook.   
Further rainfall is forecast overnight into Thursday and throughout Thursday.  
We are closely monitoring the situation.  Our incident response staff are checking defences and clearing weed screens.  
Please plan driving routes to avoid low lying roads near rivers, which may be flooded and stay aware in case further warnings are issued.  
This message will be updated on 26/09/2024, or as the situation changes.

items.description: Tern and Perry catchments
items.message:
River levels have risen at the Tern - Walcot river gauge as a result of heavy rainfall.  Flooding continues.  We expect flooding to affect low lying land and roads adjacent to the river from Wolverley to Newport. Other locations that may be affected include Market Drayton, Wem and Rodington.   
River levels have started to fall slowly but could remain high for the remainder of the week as a result of further forecast rainfall over the next 24 to 48 hours. 
We are closely monitoring the situation.  Our incident response staff are checking defences and liaising with emergency services and Local Authorities.  
Please avoid using low lying footpaths near local watercourses and plan driving routes to avoid low lying roads near rivers, which may be flooded.  
This message will be updated by 09:00 on 26/09/24, or as the situation changes.

items.description: River Trent from Cromwell Weir to Gainsborough
items.message:
River levels are still high at the Torksey river gauge as a result of heavy rainfall. Consequently, the risk of flooding to low-lying roads and farmland remains.
Areas most at risk are Church Laneham to Rampton Road.
Further heavy rainfall is forecast for this evening, Wednesday 25/09/2024, into Thursday. We expect river levels to remain high until tomorrow evening, 26/09/2024.
We are closely monitoring the situation.
Please avoid using low-lying footpaths near local watercourses and plan driving routes to avoid low-lying roads near rivers, which may be flooded.
To check the status of road closures online, please visit the One Network live map.
This message will be updated by 09:00 tomorrow, 26/09/2024, or as the situation changes.

items.description: Lower River Soar in Leicestershire
items.message:
River levels are rising at the Pillings Lock river gauge as a result of heavy rainfall.  Consequently, the risk of flooding remains.  Areas most at risk are low-lying agricultural land and roads including Slash Lane at Sileby, the Mountsorrel to Sileby Road, the B5328 Cossington Road and the access road to Sileby Mill, and farmlands at Cossington, Sileby, Barrow, Quorndon and Cotes.   
Further heavy rainfall is forecast over the next 48 hours.  We expect river levels to remain high until 27/09/24.
We are closely monitoring the situation.  
Please avoid using low-lying footpaths near local watercourses and plan driving routes to avoid low-lying roads near rivers, which may be flooded.  
To check the status of road closures online, please visit the One Network live map.
This message will be updated by 10:00 on 26/09/24, or as the situation changes.

items.description: River Trent in Derbyshire
items.message:
River levels are forecast to rise at the Willington Cableway river gauge as a result of heavy rainfall.  Consequently, flooding of roads and farmland is possible from 05:30 tomorrow, 26/09/2024.  Areas most at risk are low-lying agricultural land and roads including Willington, Barrow upon Trent, Swarkestone, Bargate Lane and the access roads to Willington Meadows, the Twyford Village access road, Church Lane at Barrow, and Ingleby Lane.   

Further heavy rainfall is forecast over the next 48 hours.  We expect river levels to remain high until Saturday, 28/09/2024.

We are closely monitoring the situation.  

Please avoid using low-lying footpaths near local watercourses and plan driving routes to avoid low-lying roads near rivers, which may be flooded.  

To check the status of road closures online, please visit the One Network live map.

This message will be updated by 09:00 tomorrow morning, 26/09/2024, or as the situation changes.

items.description: River Maun in Nottinghamshire
items.message:
River levels are forecast to rise at the Whitewater Bridge river gauge as a result of heavy rainfall later this evening and into tomorrow morning.  Consequently, flooding of roads and farmland is possible from 20:00 tonight, 25/09/2024.  Areas most at risk are low-lying agricultural land and roads around Mansfield, the Sherwood Forest Caravan Park at Clipstone, Edwinstowe, Ollerton, Whitewater Lane at Whitewater Bridge and West Drayton.   
Further rainfall is forecast over the next few days. We expect river levels to remain high until later tomorrow, 26/09/2024.
We are closely monitoring the situation.
Please avoid contact with flood water and plan driving routes to avoid low-lying roads near rivers, which may be flooded.
To check the status of road closures online, please visit the One Network live map.
This message will be updated by 09:00 on 26/09/2024, or as the situation changes.

items.description: Riseley Brook in Bedford Borough
items.message:
River levels are falling but remain high following recent rainfall.  

Flooding is possible.  

Areas most at risk are around the Riseley Brook from Riseley to Pertenhall.  

Further rainfall is forecast for Wednesday evening which may see river levels rise again at the Riseley telemetry station. 

Take care on riverside roads and footpaths, and don't put yourself in unnecessary danger.  

We are monitoring the situation. 

We will update this message by 6pm today, 25/09/2024.

items.description: Bear Brook and tributaries in the Aylesbury area, including Wendover and Weston Turville
items.message:

Flooding of low lying land and roads is therefore expected to continue today, 25/09/2024, especially in the areas closest to the Bear Brook in the urban reaches through Aylesbury. 
Further rainfall is forecast today with the potential to be heavy at times. River levels remain sensitive to further rainfall. 
Our staff are checking and clearing trash screens in the area and we are closely monitoring the situation. Avoid using low lying footpaths near local watercourses. Go to the 'River and Sea levels in England' webpage for current river levels. his message will be updated this evening, 25/09/2024, or as the situation changes.

items.description: Upper Bristol Avon area
items.message: The situation is improving on Tuesday the 24th September and river levels are falling slowly but they remain high. Further rainfall is expected on Wednesday and Thursday, it is not expected to cause flood warnings to be issued. We are monitoring the situation.

items.description: River Dene in South East Warwickshire
items.message: This Flood Alert has been removed. River levels have now fallen below the flood risk threshold. We will continue to monitor the forecast and re-issue this alert/warning if necessary. Our incident response staff are actively monitoring river levels and the weather forecast.

items.description: River Lee at Hertford
items.message:
River levels are falling on the River Lee after the heavy rainfall over the past few days. 

The Environment Agency and contractors have been in attendance at Stanstead Radial Gate, manually accommodating high flows. Flooding may continue to affect locations near the River Lee, particularly around Stanstead Lock and Tumbling Bay.

Further rain is forecast overnight and into tomorrow, so we may see rivers rise again.

We are monitoring the situation closely.

Take care and avoid walking, cycling or driving through flood water.

This message will be updated by 9am on Thursday 26th September, or as the situation changes.

Further rainfall is forecast over the next few days but no further flooding is expected for now.
We will continue to monitor the situation and will issue further alerts or warnings as necessary.
Continue to take care on waterside roads and footpaths and don't put yourself in unnecessary danger.

items.description: River Dene at Walton
Mid Bristol Avon area

floodArea.county: Bath and North East Somerset, Wiltshire

items.message:
River levels on the Bristol Avon at Bradford on Avon and Semington Brook remain high but are now falling. Flooding may still be affecting locations near the Bristol Avon, Semington Brook, with low lying land and roads expected to be most affected, particularly between Melksham and Bathford. The flood gates at Holt Road may be closed. No property flooding is currently expected.

Further flooding is possible tomorrow and Friday as river levels are forecast to rise again in response to rainfall later today and tomorrow. Weather conditions are expected to improve from Friday and river levels are forecast to fall through the weekend.

We are closely monitoring the situation and clearing debris from weed screens. Take care and avoid walking, cycling or driving through flood water. Please refer to local authority website for road closures.

This message will be updated by 2:00 PM on 26/09/2024, or as the situation changes.

items.description: Upper Nene
items.message: Over the last 48 hours we have seen heavy rainfall in the Upper River Nene area. This means that the River Nene has risen, leading to flooding of low-lying land and roads close to the river. We expect the river to remain high throughout the next few days and flooding to gardens, driveways or outhouses is possible close to the river. Our forecasts also indicate that further flooding inside properties is not likely and therefore a flood warning has been removed for areas near the Dallington Brook and Brampton Branch in Northampton. We are constantly monitoring river levels and have staff in the field checking for blockages and clearing weedscreens. Please avoid using low lying footpaths near local watercourses and plan driving routes to avoid low lying roads near rivers, which may be flooded. This message will be updated online and on FloodLine by 17:00 on 26/09/2024, or before if the situation changes.

We expect the river to remain high throughout the next few days and flooding to gardens, driveways or outhouses is possible close to the river. Our forecasts indicate that flooding inside properties is possible and therefore flood warnings may be issued. We are constantly monitoring river levels and have staff in the field checking for blockages and clearing weedscreens. Please avoid using low lying footpaths near local watercourses and plan driving routes to avoid low lying roads near rivers, which may be flooded. floodArea.county: Bracknell Forest, Surrey, Windsor and Maidenhead

items.message:
Property flooding is not currently expected. River levels have risen on the Chertsey Bourne as a result of heavy rain over the few days. Therefore, flooding of low lying land and roads is expected today - 25/09/2024 , especially in the areas closest to the Free Prae Road area of Chertsey.
 Further heavier rainfall is forecast today 25/09/24. River levels are expected to remain high for several days. 
Our staff are checking and clearing trash screens. We are monitoring the situation. Avoid using low lying footpaths near local watercourses. Go to the 'River and Sea levels in England' webpage for current river levels. This message will be updated this evening, 25/09/2024, or as the situation changes.

items.description: River Leadon catchment
items.message:
River levels are falling but remain high at the Wedderburn Bridge river gauge as a result of localised thunderstorms. Consequently, the risk of flooding of roads and farmland is still possible. 
We expect flooding to affect low lying land and roads adjacent to the River Leadon. Locations that may be affected include Ledbury, Much Marcle, Staunton and Tibberton. Water may be out of bank at Upleadon Court. 
Further rainfall is forecast in the next 24 hours. 
We are closely monitoring the situation.
Please see the GOV.UK website for a 5-day flood forecast and avoid contact with flood water.
This message will be updated by 09:00 tomorrow, 26/09/2024, or as the situation changes.

items.description: River Severn in Gloucestershire
items.message:
River levels remain high at the Tewkesbury Upper Pound river gauge following recent heavy rainfall. 
Consequently, flooding of roads and farmland is expected to continue. 
We expect flooding to affect low lying land and roads adjacent to the River Severn from Tewkesbury to Gloucester. Locations that may be affected include Apperley and Maisemore. Severn Ham, Tewkesbury starts to fill. 
Predicted peaks: Mythe, Haw Bridge, Sandhurst and Gloucester have all peaked and are steady. 
Further rainfall is forecast in the next 24 hours. We are closely monitoring the situation. 
Please see the GOV.UK website for a 5-day flood forecast, and plan driving routes to avoid low lying roads near rivers, which may be flooded. 
This message will be updated by 09:00 tomorrow, 26/09/2024, or as the situation changes.

items.description: River Adur East Branch
items.message: The River Adur has now fallen significantly. There is uncertainty in the weather forecast, but light rain on Wednesday (25/09/2024) followed by possible heavy showers through the early hours of Thursday could cause river levels to rise again. From 10:00 on 26/09/2024, minor flooding and small amounts of water could affect fields, gardens and possibly the A281 at Mock Bridge, near Shermanbury. The river should peak lower than it was on Monday, and begin to fall by 22:00 on 26/09/2024. However, it is possible that another period of persistent rain with intense showers could occur throughout Thursday and into Friday (27/09/2024), which would cause river levels to rise higher. There is confidence in less rain occurring from Friday afternoon and through the weekend, which should allow river levels to return nearer to normal by Saturday afternoon at the latest. Some roads, including the A281 at Mock Bridge, may be affected. Please plan to avoid driving through routes vulnerable to flooding. We continue to monitor the levels and forecast. We will update this message by 11:00 on 26/09/2024.

items.message: Heavy rain fell in the Nene catchment earlier this week which has caused the River Nene to rise. Low lying areas near the River are flooded and properties from Cogenhoe to Great Doddington may continue to be affected today, Wednesday 25 September. Further rainfall is expected today and into Thursday morning and river levels are expected to remain high. Remain safe and be aware of your local surroundings. Please avoid contact with flood water. Our staff are out in the area to check the flood defences, clear blockages, and assist the emergency services and council. We will be closely monitoring the situation and this message will be updated online and on FloodLine by 17:00 on 26/09/24, or before if the situation changes.

items.description: River Thame at Dorchester
items.message:
Property flooding is expected. River levels have risen on the River Thame as a result of recent heavy rainfall. Therefore, flooding of property is expected today, 25/09/24, especially those properties closest to the river. Further rainfall is forecast today with the potential to be heavy at times. We expect river levels to remain high and sensitive to further rainfall. 
Move possessions and valuables off the ground or to safety. Go to the 'River and Sea levels in England' webpage for current river levels. This message will be updated by this evening, 25/09/24, or as the situation changes.

items.description: River Great Ouse at New Bradwell and Haversham
items.message: River levels are beginning to fall slowly but remain high in the lower catchment in response to recent rainfall. Flooding is expected. Areas most at risk are Newport Road and Wooton Court in New Bradwell, Haversham Sailing Club and Haversham Mill. Further rainfall is forecast throughout Wednesday which will keep river levels high. Take care on riverside roads and footpaths, and don't put yourself in unnecessary danger. We are monitoring the situation and will update this message by 4pm today, 25/09/2024

items.description: River Leam at Leamington A
River Cherwell from below Banbury to just above Upper Heyford
items.message: This flood warning has been removed. River levels have now fallen below the flood risk threshold. The flood warning for the area has now been removed. However, a flood alert remains in force for the wider area, so flooding may still affect roads and low lying land. Further rainfall is forecast over the next few days and we will monitor its impacts Avoid using low lying footpaths near local watercourses. Avoid contact with flood water.

items.description: River Nene in Wellingborough
items.message: Heavy rain fell in the Nene catchment earlier this week which has caused the River Nene to rise. Low lying areas near to the river are flooded and properties in Wellingborough to continue to be affected today, Wednesday 25 September. Further rainfall is expected today and into Thursday morning and river levels are expected to remain high. Remain safe and be aware of your local surroundings. Please avoid contact with flood water.  Our staff are out in the area to check the flood defences, clear blockages, and assist the emergency services and council.  We will be closely monitoring the situation and this message will be updated online and on FloodLine by 17:00 on 26/09/2024, or before if the situation changes.

items.description: Properties closest to the River Ock from Tesco to St. Helen's Wharf
items.message:
Property flooding is expected. River levels are rising on the River Ock as a result of recent heavy rainfall. Therefore, flooding of properties closest to the river is expected today, 25/09/24, in the Abingdon area. Areas most at risk are Nash Drive, Chaunterell Way,  Mill Paddock, Orpwood Way and St Helens Mill. Further rainfall is forecast today with the potential to be heavy at times. We expect river levels to continue to rise slowly today as levels remain sensitive to further rainfall.
Our staff are liaising with councils and emergency services. We are monitoring the situation. Move possessions and valuables off the ground or to safety.  Activate any property flood protection products such as flood barriers. This message will be updated by this evening, 25/09/24, or as the situation changes.

items.description: River Thame from Chiselhampton to Drayton St Leonard
items.message:
Property flooding is possible. River levels are rising on the River Thame as a result of recent heavy rainfall. Therefore, flooding of property and roads is possible this today, 25/09/24, especially in the Stadhampton area. Further rainfall is forecast today with the potential to be heavy at times. We expect river levels to remain high and sensitive to further rainfall. 
Move possessions and valuables off the ground or to safety. Go to the 'River and Sea levels in England' webpage for current river levels. This message will be updated by this evening, 25/09/24, or as the situation changes.

items.description: River Cherwell from Lower Heyford down to Cherwell Bridge
items.message:
Property flooding is expected. River levels are high on the River Cherwell as a result of recent heavy rainfall. Therefore, flooding of property and roads is expected to continue today, 25/09/24, in the Heyford Bridge and Enslow areas. Areas most at risk include Watermead Road, Kidlington. Further rainfall is forecast today with the potential to be heavy at times. River levels are expected to rise again this afternoon in response to forecast rainfall. 
Our staff are liaising with councils and emergency services. We are monitoring the situation. Move possessions and valuables off the ground or to safety. Activate any property flood protection products such as flood barriers. This message will be updated by this evening, 25/09/24, or as the situation changes.

items.description: River Ray for Islip
items.message:
Property flooding is expected. River levels are rising on the River Ray as a result of recent heavy rainfall. Therefore, flooding of property and roads is expected today, 25/09/24, especially in the Islip area.  Areas most at risk include Mill Street. Further rainfall is forecast today with the potential to be heavy at times. We expect river levels to continue to rise slowly today and overnight. 
Our staff are liaising with councils and emergency services.  Move possessions and valuables off the ground or to safety. Move family, pets and cars to safety. This message will be updated by this evening, 25/09/24, or as the situation changes.

items.description: River Ray from the Heath Bridge area to and including the Otmoor Basin

floodArea.riverOrSea: River Ray, Studley Wood Brook, Beckley Brook

items.message:
Property flooding is expected. River levels are rising on the River Ray as a result of very heavy rainfall yesterday. Therefore, flooding of property and roads is expected today, 25/09/24, especially in the Murcott and Otmoor area. Further rainfall is forecast today with the potential to be heavy at times. We expect river levels to continue to rise slowly today and overnight. 
Our staff are liaising with councils and emergency services.  Move possessions and valuables off the ground or to safety. Move family, pets and cars to safety. This message will be updated by tomorrow morning, 25/09/24, or as the situation changes.

items.description: Low lying areas close to the River Great Ouse and River Ouzel at Newport Pagnell
items.message: River levels are beginning to fall following recent heavy rainfall but remain responsive to further rainfall. Flooding is expected. Areas most at risk are Caldecote Lane, Willen Road, River Side, Toll House, Woad Farm, Sherington Road and Gallards Farm in Newport Pagnell, and Ravenstone Mill in Ravenstone.  Take care on low lying roads and footpaths, and don't put yourself in unnecessary danger. We are monitoring the situation and will update this message by 4pm today, 25/09/24.

items.description: Low lying areas close to the River Great Ouse at Fulwell, Radclive and Buckingham
items.message: River levels are now steadily falling, but remain quite high in some locations and responsive to further rainfall. A Flood Alert remains in force for the wider area. The forecast is for further rainfall throughout Wednesday which may cause the river levels to rise again. There may still be some areas where flood water is present until it can naturally drain away.  We will continue to monitor levels closely.

items.description: Wider area at risk from the River Great Ouse at Fulwell, Radclive and Buckingham
items.message: River levels are now steadily falling, but remain quite high in some locations and responsive to further rainfall. A Flood Alert remains in force for the wider area. The forecast is for further rainfall throughout Wednesday which may cause the river levels to rise again. There may still be some areas where flood water is present until it can naturally drain away.  We will continue to monitor levels closely.

items.description: River Ock at Abingdon and Caldecott
items.message: Property flooding is expected. River levels are rising on the River Ock as a result of a period of sustained rain. Therefore, flooding of property has already occurred but wider flooding impacts are imminent. Peak levels will be higher than January 2024, however they will be significantly lower than July 2007.  Chauntrelle Way, Orpwood Way and Nash Drive are the most vulnerable.  Further rainfall is forecast over the next 48 hours. We expect river levels to remain high today and overnight We are monitoring the situation. Our staff are liaising with councils and emergency services. Go to the 'River and Sea levels in England' webpage for current river levels.) Move possessions and valuables off the ground or to safety and do not drive or walk through flood water. This message will be updated by this afternoon, 25/09/2024, or as the situation changes.

items.description: River Great Ouse at Harrold
items.message:
River levels are rising following recent heavy rainfall. Flooding is expected. 

Areas most at risk are The Green, Church Walk, High Street, Hall Close, Carlton Road and Harrold and Odell Country Park in Harrold.  

Further rainfall is forecast this evening, 25/09/2024 which will keep river levels high. Take care on riverside roads and footpaths, and don't put yourself in unnecessary danger. 

We are monitoring the situation. We will update this message by 4pm today, 25/09/24.

items.description: River Ivel at Sandy
items.message:
River levels are high following recent heavy rainfall. Flooding is expected from now until tomorrow morning, 26/09/24.

Areas most at risk are New Road, Bedford Road, Girtford Bridge, Great North Road, Rivermead Gardens, Mcmurdo Court, London Road, Church Path, Spring Grove, Poplar Close. Girtford Crescent, Sandford Rise, BrayBrook, All Hallows, Elmtree Road, Manor Road, Bickerdikes Gardens and Nursery Drive.  

Further rainfall is forecast this evening, 25/09/2024 which will keep river levels high. Take care on riverside roads and footpaths, and don't put yourself in unnecessary danger. 

We are monitoring the situation. We will update this message by 9am tomorrow, 26/09/24.
